bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, June 27, 1729

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Weymouth merchant Edward Tucker, June 27, 1729, about the poor tobacco sales in that port that Tucker has reported to him, the damage to goods Tucker has sent him, places orders for Dorset and Southam ales to replace that he has lost in the fine that destroyed his house, and the caterpillers that have destroyed much of the fruit crops.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, June 27, 1729

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
June the 27th. 1729
Edward Tucker, Esqr.

div1.p:
No ship coming directly from you this Year obliges me to
write to you Via London.

Yor. last Letters bears date the 14th. of Octor. and the 9th. of Decr.
it is a miserable storey you tell of Tobbo: that it is so bad you had no Encourage
ment to Continue in it. Wee must live in hopes of its mending. Capt. Wilson is an
unfortunate man. I am always a Considerable Suferer by his ship, but I
hope not so bad as you are in doubt of. The Malt and the Beer you sent by the
Harrison I rec'd but I cannot Say Safe, The hampers were so abused that wt.
with Theivery and what with Breakage I lost one third of it. This I sufer
every way.

By my loss by fire of which no doubt you will hear I was
rendred very poor in Liquor. the Cheese and the sloopsSailes I Expect you will send me
in Early the next fall And I desire you to send me in also four hogsheads of the best
Dorset Ale well and Carefully packt up into Bottles that I may be able to pay my Debts I hope I shall have
better luck with it then the last, There hath bin no Opportunity of sending
Tobbo: to your Port Else I should have found Some for you Altho if your
Markets remain as bad as you Say they were there will be little diference
between burning and shiping of it these are dreadfull Consideracions
to us that have no other trade to maintain our familys by, I must desire
you to send me also a hogshead of your best Malt.

herein I send you Colonel Hacks Exchange on yor.self for £3"—
which you will please to Credit my Accot. with or Protest.

Wee have had a dismall Judgemt. upon our fruit trees these
two Years together by Caterpillars however the last year wee made a great deel of
Cyder that was Extraordinary good and if I had not loss [sic] in my bottles in the Cellar
fire I could have Stockd myself Plentifully for 2 Yrs. but now it is all Prickt &
Spoild and wee have the least fruit upon the Trees that ever I saw so that I must
desire you if You can meet with any that is right good to send me a hogshead
of Southam well and Carefully bottled of, and Safely pack'd I am
div1.closer:
Sir
Yor. most humble Servt.-
per Baily

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1727 April 13-1728 July 23, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity to the heading on the draft.
[1] A Captain Wilson is mentioned in Carter's letter to Edward Tucker of 1721 May 27 as having arrived after "15 weeks passage." and in his 1723 diary.
[2] Carter had built a fine house at Corotoman in the mid-1720s, but it burned in January 1729. See the Maryland Gazette for 1728/29 February 4-11 for information about Carter's loss.
[3] Southam is a type of English ale.

[4] The Bailey was a London ship owned by William Dawkins and commanded at various times by Adam Graves (1725-1730) and by Thomas Dove (1731-1732). She was a vessel of some 250 tons and carried 15-17 crew members. (Survey report 6801 summarizing Adm. 68/195, 156v, and other data in Adm. 68/194 and /196, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia; A letter of Carter's executors to Dawkins 1738 May 10 refers to "your ship Bailey.")
